title: Assignment 1
text:
Generative art example:
Works by Michael Hansmeyer, an architect using computational and algorithmic architecture techniques. https://www.michael-hansmeyer.com/projects  



Fall image using the color option: “darkorange2”



Critique of a chart:
Bartlett, K. (2022, October 31). Survey: Africans See China as Positive Force. VOA. https://www.voanews.com/a/survey-africans-see-china-as-positive-force/6813313.html
This VOA article is based on a public opinion surveys conducted in 25 countries on views toward China, the US, and Taiwan. The article makes the argument that people in Africa are more supportive of China, while people from other parts of the world hold negative views about China. It only shows one bar graph of one variable – respondents with a negative view toward China, which is actually a counterintuitive way to graph opinion polls, as we often associate bar graphs indicating % of views with positive views.

title: Assignment 3
text:
Anscombe’s quartet of linear regressions using ggplot2
Reference for code: Sanjana P (2023, March 13). RPubs. Anscombe’s quartet.
https://rpubs.com/Sanjana01/1014918

# Load the ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

# Load the Anscombe's Quartet dataset
data("anscombe")

# Scatter plots
p1 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x1, y=y1)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 1")

p2 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x2, y=y2)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 2")

p3 <-ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x3, y=y3)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 3")

p4 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, mapping=aes(x=x4, y=y4)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 4")

grid.arrange(p1, p2, p3, p4, nrow = 2, ncol = 2, 
             top = "Anscombe's Quartet of Linear Regressions (using ggplot2)")



# fit linear model
lm1 = lm(anscombe$y1~anscombe$x1)
lm2 = lm(anscombe$y2~anscombe$x2)
lm3 = lm(anscombe$y3~anscombe$x3)
lm4 = lm(anscombe$y4~anscombe$x4)

# combine scatter plot with linear model
p1 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x1, y=y1)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 1") +
  geom_smooth(method="lm", color = "blue",se=FALSE)

p2 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x2, y=y2)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 2") +
  geom_smooth(method="lm", color = "blue",se=FALSE)

p3 <-ggplot(data=anscombe, aes(x=x3, y=y3)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 3") +
  geom_smooth(method="lm", color = "blue",se=FALSE)

p4 <- ggplot(data=anscombe, mapping=aes(x=x4, y=y4)) + 
  geom_point(color = "orange") + 
  labs(title="Pair 4") +
  geom_smooth(method="lm", color = "blue",se=FALSE)

grid.arrange(p1, p2, p3, p4, nrow = 2, ncol = 2,
             top = "Anscombe's Quartet of Linear Regressions (using ggplot2)")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Assignment 4
text:
Part of Assignment 4 (hackathon) No. 3 barchart:

library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

# Load the USArrests dataset
data(USArrests)

# Arrange the data frame by the "Murder" variable in ascending order
USArrests_sorted_murder <- USArrests[order(USArrests$Murder), ]

# Create the flipped bar chart for "Murder" by states
plot_murder <- ggplot(USArrests_sorted_murder, aes(x = Murder, y = reorder(rownames(USArrests_sorted_murder), Murder))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "red") +
  labs(x = "Murder arrests", y = "State") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 1))

# Reuse the same ordering for the "Assault" chart
plot_assault <- ggplot(USArrests_sorted_murder, aes(x = Assault, y = reorder(rownames(USArrests_sorted_murder), Murder))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "orange") +
  labs(x = "Assault arrests", y = "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_blank())  # Remove y-axis labels for the second plot

# Combine both plots side by side
grid.arrange(plot_murder, plot_assault, ncol = 2,
             top = "Murder and Assult Rates by State (per 100,000 residents) 
             (Source: R dataset: Violent Crime Rates by US State (USArrest))")
